results.headline: Beyond the Casting Couch. Way Beyond.
results.summary_short: Giving in to a lecher might help a young actress get her foot in the door, but when the soul follows, as it does in “Starry Eyes,” the trouble begins.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Starry Eyes

results.headline: A Journalist Imprisoned in Iran, Escaping With Ghosts
results.summary_short: “Rosewater,” from Jon Stewart, tells the story of an Iranian-born journalist who was arrested in Iran in 2009 and accused of being an agent for foreign intelligence organizations.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Rosewater

results.headline: The Seeds of an Urban Protest
results.summary_short: “Occupy the Farm,” directed by Todd Darling, looks at a 2012 grass-roots standoff over plans to sell a section of farmland owned by the University of California.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Occupy the Farm

results.headline: A Teacher on a Mission to Erase Evil
results.summary_short: There is more under the surface than a moviegoer might guess on first glance at “Miss Meadows,” whose title character is played by Katie Holmes.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Miss Meadows

results.display_title: Levitated Mass: The Story of Michael Heizer's Monolithic Sculpture
results.headline: Surreal Journey of a Rock That Would Be Art
results.summary_short: “Levitated Mass” chronicles the transport of a 340-ton boulder through Southern California to a sculptor’s installation at the Los Angeles County Museum of Art.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Levitated Mass: The Story of Michael Heizer's Monolithic Sculpture

results.headline: Cursed by Guilt and a Creepy Sense That Punishment Is Coming
results.summary_short: Kiyoshi Kurosawa’s “Penance” follows four young women who were traumatized by a classmate’s murder and by their own puzzling failure to identify the killer.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Penance

results.headline: To Save Us All From Satan’s Power
results.summary_short: In “Kirk Cameron’s Saving Christmas,” Mr. Cameron stages his version of an intervention to bolster seasonal cheer and put the Bible back in the holidays.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Kirk Cameron's Saving Christmas

results.headline: When the ‘Pure-Blood’ Sort Are Cannibals
results.summary_short: In “Wolves,” directed by David Hayter, a teenager awakens from a terrible dream to find that his parents have been killed and that he is acquiring lupine form.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Wolves

results.headline: Like a Wiser Dorothy’s Yen for Kansas
results.summary_short: “Always Woodstock” centers on an aspiring singer-songwriter who strikes out in New York City and moves back to her childhood home.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Always Woodstock

results.headline: Then We Could Swing a Cat From a Chandelier
results.summary_short: “Dumb and Dumber To” reunites Jim Carrey and Jeff Daniels, adds Kathleen Turner and relies heavily on diaper gags.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Dumb and Dumber To

results.display_title: Drug Lord: The Legend Of Shorty
results.headline: On the Trail of a Fearsome Escape Artist
results.summary_short: In “Drug Lord: The Legend of Shorty,” filmmakers set out to find the kingpin Joaquín Guzmán Loera, obtaining remarkable access to insiders in Mexico’s criminal culture.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Drug Lord: The Legend Of Shorty

results.headline: The Woods Are Dark and So, So Deep
results.summary_short: Two movies directed by Josephine Decker, “Butter on the Latch” and “Thou Wast Mild & Lovely,” revel in cryptic lyricism.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Butter on the Latch

results.headline: Like Father, Unlike Son
results.summary_short: “Brahmin Bulls,” Mahesh Pailoor’s debut feature, is a father-and-son story that hinges on an interesting complication of sympathies.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Brahmin Bulls

results.headline: Let the Drinking Games and Self-Pity Begin
results.summary_short: In Chris Lowell’s “Beside Still Waters,” a weekend reunion of old high school friends turns into whiskey-lubricated nostalgia.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Beside Still Waters

results.headline: Cotton Mills, Venom and Dead Ends
results.summary_short: Zeke and Simon Hawkins’s “Bad Turn Worse” begins with $20,000 missing from a safe in a Texas cotton mill town.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Bad Turn Worse

results.headline: Gorillas in the Midst of a Battle Over Oil
results.summary_short: In “Virunga,” a national park in the Democratic Republic of Congo with rare mountain gorillas is a battleground over oil drilling and conservation.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Virunga

results.headline: Matters of the (Young) Heart
results.summary_short: A young man who happens to be blind begins to indulge his independence and understand his sexuality in “The Way He Looks.”

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Hoje Eu Quero Voltar Sozinho

results.headline: It’s a Plane! No, It’s a Bird
results.summary_short: “Pelican Dreams” is a study of California’s brown pelicans by Judy Irving, the director of “The Wild Parrots of Telegraph Hill.”

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Pelican Dreams

results.headline: A Director’s Gift
results.summary_short: “21 Years: Richard Linklater,” by Michael Dunaway and Tara Wood, offers a star-studded tribute to the director of “Boyhood,” “School of Rock” and “Slacker.”

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of 21 Years: Richard Linklater

results.display_title: Why Don't You Play in Hell?
results.headline: When Yakuza Meets the Movies
results.summary_short: A starlet from a crime family, an aimless movie director and lots of violent types populate Sion Sono’s “Why Don’t You Play in Hell?”

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Why Don't You Play in Hell?
